results.question: What plan does Friar Lawrence propose for Juliet to avoid marrying Paris?
results.reference_answer: Friar Lawrence proposes that Juliet take a vial of distilled liquor that will make her appear dead for forty-two hours, allowing her to avoid marrying Paris and enabling Romeo to rescue her.
results.generated_answer: Friar Lawrence’s plan is that Juliet should appear to consent to the wedding, then the night before marry­ing take a potion he gives her that will make her seem dead for "two and forty hours." She will be laid out in the Capulet tomb as if dead; meanwhile Friar Lawrence will send a message to Romeo in Mantua so Romeo can come, meet Juliet when she awakes, and carry her off to Mantua. In short: a feigned death to avoid the marriage and allow Juliet and Romeo to flee together.

Relevance: 53%
FRIAR LAWRENCE.
Hold, daughter. I do spy a kind of hope,
Which craves as desperate an execution
As that is desperate which we would prevent.
If, rather than to marry County Paris
Thou hast the strength of will to slay thyself,
Then is it likely thou wilt undertake
A thing like death to chide away this shame,
That cop’st with death himself to scape from it.
And if thou dar’st, I’ll give thee remedy.

JULIET.
O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris,
From off the battlements of yonder tower,
Or walk in thievish ways, or bid me lurk
Where serpents are. Chain me with roaring bears;
Or hide me nightly in a charnel-house,
O’er-cover’d quite with dead men’s rattling bones,
With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls.
Or bid me go into a new-made grave,
And hide me with a dead man in his shroud;
Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble,
And I will do it without fear or doubt,
To live an unstain’d wife to my sweet love.

FRIAR LAWRENCE.
Hold then. Go home, be merry, give consent
To marry Paris. Wednesday is tomorrow;
Tomorrow night look that thou lie alone,
Let not thy Nurse lie with thee in thy chamber.
Take thou this vial, being then in bed,
And this distilled liquor drink thou off,
When presently through all thy veins shall run
A cold and drowsy humour; for no pulse
Shall keep his native progress, but surcease.
No warmth, no breath shall testify thou livest,
The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade
To paly ashes; thy eyes’ windows fall,
Like death when he shuts up the day of life.
Each part depriv’d of supple government,
Shall stiff and stark and cold appear like death.
And in this borrow’d likeness of shrunk death
Thou shalt continue two and forty hours,
And then awake as from a pleasant sleep.
Now when the bridegroom in the morning comes
To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead.
Then as the manner of our country is,
In thy best robes, uncover’d, on the bier,
Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault
Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.
In the meantime, against thou shalt awake,
Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift,
And hither shall he come, and he and I
Will watch thy waking, and that very night
Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua.
And this shall free thee from this present shame,
If no inconstant toy nor womanish fear
Abate thy valour in the acting it.

results.question: What does Juliet suggest about names and their significance while speaking to Romeo?
results.reference_answer: Juliet suggests that a name is not essential to a person's identity, stating that a rose would smell sweet by any other name and that Romeo would retain his perfection without his name, indicating that she values him over the Montague name.
results.generated_answer: Juliet argues that names are arbitrary social labels that do not change the true nature of a person. She tells Romeo to “deny thy father and refuse thy name” and insists “‘Tis but thy name that is my enemy; / Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.” Her famous line—“What’s in a name? That which we call a rose / By any other name would smell as sweet”—sums up the idea: the qualities that make Romeo himself remain the same regardless of his family name. In short, she sees the name “Montague” as irrelevant to who he really is and urges that love should transcend the social identity imposed by names (even though the play later shows those names carry powerful social consequences).

results.question: What does Romeo express about his feelings when asked about his sadness by Benvolio?

results.question: What does Mercutio compare Benvolio to in their conversation about being quick to anger?
results.reference_answer: Mercutio compares Benvolio to a fellow who enters a tavern, puts his sword on the table, and claims he does not want to use it, only to draw it out when no need arises.
results.generated_answer: Mercutio says Benvolio is like “one of these fellows” who, on entering a tavern, claps his sword on the table and declares “God send me no need of thee!” — i.e., a swaggering tavern‑brawler who provokes a fight after a drink. He also calls him “as hot a Jack in thy mood as any in Italy” and says Benvolio’s “head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat.”

results.question: What warning does Friar Lawrence give to Romeo about love in the text?
results.reference_answer: Friar Lawrence warns Romeo that "These violent delights have violent ends" and advises him to "love moderately" because too much haste can be as detrimental as too much slowness.
results.generated_answer: Friar Lawrence warns Romeo that intense, sudden passion is dangerous and self-destructive. He says, famously, “These violent delights have violent ends, / And in their triumph die; like fire and powder, / Which as they kiss consume,” and goes on, “Therefore love moderately: long love doth so; / Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.” In other words, extreme, hasty love can burn out or end badly; Romeo should love with moderation and steadiness. (Act 2, Scene 6.)
